summary: This document is a compilation of news clips from August 20, 2019, covering multiple cases in the Southern District of New York. It includes significant updates on the Michael Avenatti extortion case, the posthumous dismissal of charges against Jeffrey Epstein with continued investigation into co-conspirators, and other unrelated cases. The Epstein section details his death, the motion to drop charges, the investigation into his associates, and allegations against Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Michael Avenatti
persons.context: Embattled attorney facing federal extortion charges related to Nike and embezzlement charges from other clients. He is arguing that his actions were protected litigation activity.

persons.name: Scott A. Srebnick
persons.context: One of Avenatti's Florida-based attorneys representing him in the Nike extortion case.

persons.name: Jose M. Quinon
persons.context: One of Avenatti's Florida-based attorneys representing him in the Nike extortion case.

persons.name: Gary Franklin Sr.
persons.context: Avenatti's client, a California youth basketball coach, who allegedly had evidence of Nike funneling money to recruits.

persons.name: Stephanie Clifford
persons.context: Adult-film star known as Stormy Daniels, a former client of Avenatti who he is accused of stealing from.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.context: The U.S. Attorney who commented on the Avenatti case and filed the motion to drop charges against Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Financier accused of sex trafficking who died by suicide in jail. Prosecutors moved to drop charges posthumously but vowed to continue investigating co-conspirators.

persons.name: Richard Berman
persons.context: Judge presiding over the Epstein case who was asked to dismiss the indictment.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Vowed to investigate Epstein's death and continue the case against any co-conspirators. Ordered personnel changes at the Bureau of Prisons.

persons.name: Hugh Hurwitz
persons.role: Acting Director of Bureau of Prisons
persons.context: Was removed from his position by Attorney General Barr following Epstein's death.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: British socialite accused in lawsuits of being Epstein's co-conspirator in his sex trafficking ring. Her whereabouts were unknown.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Former friend of Epstein mentioned in the context of Avenatti's representation of Stormy Daniels and Epstein's social connections.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Former friend of Epstein mentioned in the context of Epstein's social connections.

persons.name: Bill Gates
persons.context: Met with Epstein. His former science adviser was named in Epstein's will.

persons.name: Boris Nikolic
persons.context: Bill Gates' former science adviser named as a successor executor in Epstein's will. He distanced himself from the role.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.context: Longtime Epstein employee named as an executor of his estate.

persons.name: George Mitchell
persons.context: Named in unsealed court documents as someone an alleged victim was directed to have sex with. He denied the allegations.

persons.name: Bill Richardson
persons.context: Named in unsealed court documents as someone an alleged victim was directed to have sex with. He denied the allegations.

persons.name: Marvin Minsky
persons.context: Named in unsealed court documents as someone an alleged victim was directed to have sex with.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.context: Named in unsealed court documents as someone an alleged victim was directed to have sex with.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein's former cellmate at the MCC. His attorney claims guards are threatening him since Epstein's death.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Attorney for Nicholas Tartaglione, who filed a letter to a judge about threats from guards and poor jail conditions.

persons.name: Kenneth Karas
persons.context: White Plains federal judge to whom Tartaglione's attorney wrote regarding his client's treatment.

persons.name: John Pierre Dupont
persons.context: Accused of running fake political PAC websites to steal donations. He jumped bail and is a fugitive.

persons.name: Jesus Prado
persons.context: HIV-positive immigrant suing ICE and agents over improper medical care and illegal arrest.

connections.description: Srebnick is one of Avenatti's defense attorneys in the Nike extortion case.
Quinon is one of Avenatti's defense attorneys in the Nike extortion case.
Franklin was Avenatti's client in the potential lawsuit against Nike.
Avenatti was previously Clifford's (Stormy Daniels) attorney and is accused of stealing from her.
Maxwell is alleged in lawsuits to have been Epstein's co-conspirator in maintaining a sex trafficking ring.
Epstein named Nikolic as a successor executor in his will, indicating a financial/advisor relationship.
Indyke is described as a longtime Epstein employee and an executor of his estate.
Tartaglione was briefly Epstein's cellmate at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.
An alleged victim claims Maxwell directed her to have sex with Mitchell, though he denies it.
An alleged victim claims Maxwell directed her to have sex with Richardson, though he denies it.
Barket is Tartaglione's attorney, filing motions on his behalf regarding jail conditions.

events.title: Avenatti Motion to Dismiss Filed
events.description: Michael Avenatti's attorneys filed a motion to dismiss the Nike extortion indictment, arguing his actions were protected litigation activity.

events.title: Motion to Drop Epstein Charges
events.description: U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman filed a motion to dismiss the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein due to his death, while vowing to continue investigating co-conspirators.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein hanged himself in his Manhattan jail cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Epstein's First Suicide Attempt
events.description: Epstein was found with neck injuries in his cell, which was shared with Nicholas Tartaglione at the time.

events.title: Tartaglione Alleges Threats
events.description: Nicholas Tartaglione's attorney filed a letter claiming MCC guards have been threatening Tartaglione since Epstein's death to prevent him from sharing information.

events.title: Epstein Signs Will
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed his will two days before his suicide, showing an estate worth nearly $580 million transferred to a trust.

events.title: Dupont Fugitive Status Confirmed
events.description: Federal authorities confirmed that John Pierre Dupont, accused of fraud via fake PAC websites, jumped bail and is a fugitive.

locations: U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
St. Thomas (where Epstein's will was filed)
keyFacts: Prosecutors moved to drop charges against Jeffrey Epstein following his suicide but vowed to continue investigating his co-conspirators, with Attorney General Barr promising accountability.
Ghislaine Maxwell is explicitly named in the document as an alleged co-conspirator who participated in Epstein's sex trafficking ring, with her whereabouts unknown post-Epstein's death.
Epstein's will, signed two days before his death, valued his estate at nearly $580 million and named Bill Gates' former science adviser Boris Nikolic as a successor executor.
Unsealed court documents allege that an accuser was directed by Maxwell to have sex with several powerful figures including George Mitchell, Bill Richardson, and Jean-Luc Brunel.
Nicholas Tartaglione, Epstein's former cellmate, alleged through his attorney that MCC guards were threatening him to prevent him from sharing information about Epstein's suicide and jail conditions.
